title: Pull Request
text: Please include summary change issue fixed. Please also include relevant motivation context. List dependencies required change. Bug fix (non-breaking change fixes issue) New feature (non-breaking change adds functionality) Breaking change (fix feature cause existing functionality work expected) Documentation update

title: Pull Request
text: Fixes # (issue number)

title: Pull Request
text: Please describe tests ran verify changes. Provide instructions others can reproduce. Include details testing environment. Test Test B

title: Pull Request
text: code follows style guidelines project performed self-review code commented code, particularly hard--understand areas made corresponding changes documentation changes generate new warnings added tests prove fix effective feature works New existing unit tests pass locally changes

title: Pull Request
text: Provide screenshots feature fix help review.

title: Pull Request
text: Add context information pull request .

title: How to contribute to jsar
text: jsar contributing guidelines 0.1.0 Everyone welcome contribute code, documentation, testing, suggestions. jsar package designed beginner-friendly. Whether ’re new open-source, coding, GitHub, encourage try submitting pull requests (PRs). can contribute exploring code, improving documentation, enhancing tests. always typos fix, docs clarify, details add, code document, tests write. Even smallest PRs valuable appreciated. Getting started important step! ’ll discover whole new world collaboration learning. Fork jsar repo, make changes, submit . ’ll work together make best can !

what: I want to help, but I don’t know where to start
title: How to contribute to jsar
text: Check issue section find features, ideas, bugs can work . can also open new issue just let us know ’re interested helping . ’ll gladly suggest tasks match skill level.

title: How to contribute to jsar
text: ’ve found bug, first illustrate bug minimal example. file GitHub repo issue section.

title: How to contribute to jsar
text: Documentation high priority jsar pull requests correct improve documentation welcome. important thing know jsar packages use roxygen2; means documentation found R code close source function.

title: How to contribute to jsar
text: experienced programmer, might want help package development. pull request, always file issue make sure someone jsar team agrees ’s problem, happy basic proposal fixing . don’t want spend bunch time something don’t think good idea.

title: How to contribute to jsar
text: Don’t let impostor syndrome hold back! Every suggestion opinion valuable. Even ’s just thought, feedback always welcome. Go issue section add idea.

title: Collection of useful R funtions
text: goal jsar package provide comprehensive toolset collates functions data science analyst communities. bringing together diverse range functions one package, simplifies process accessing utilizing resources, thereby offering invaluable help users. ease access reduces time spent searching right tools also increases overall productivity, enabling analysts focus deriving insights less manual processes. Furthermore, jsar package designed foster collaboration across teams providing unified platform team members can share leverage tools data structures. collaborative environment encourages consistency, enhances communication, ultimately drives effective innovative problem-solving.

title: Calculates the change — calc_change
text: calc_change calculates level change column dataframe specified amount time, calc_change_per calculates percentage change column dataframe specified amount time.

title: Calculates the change — calc_change
code: calc_change(column, len, dt)  calc_change_per(column, len, dt)

title: Calculates the change — calc_change
text: column column use calculating change. len number lags use. dt date column order column values .

title: Calculates the change — calc_change
text: vector containing change values.

title: Calculates the change — calc_change
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  lfs_state %>% group_by(date) %>% summarise(emp = sum(emp), .groups = 'drop') %>% mutate(chng = calc_change(emp, 1, date)) #> # A tibble: 152 × 3 #>    date         emp   chng #>    <date>     <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1 1986-08-01 6919.  NA    #>  2 1986-11-01 7034. 116.   #>  3 1987-02-01 7022. -11.9  #>  4 1987-05-01 7104.  81.3  #>  5 1987-08-01 7092. -11.3  #>  6 1987-11-01 7182.  89.9  #>  7 1988-02-01 7247.  65.1  #>  8 1988-05-01 7355. 108.   #>  9 1988-08-01 7353.  -1.55 #> 10 1988-11-01 7509. 155.   #> # ℹ 142 more rows

title: Comparing models — compare_models
text: Comparing models

title: Comparing models — compare_models
text: models statistical model object list statistical model objects. Lists models can specified models = list(model.1, model.2, ...). Different object types can also mixed. model_names character vector labels model names. default, models named "mod_1", "mod_2", etc. Specifying model_names = c("Model name 1", "Model name 2") etc. overrides default behavior.

title: Comparing models — compare_models
text: dataframe compared models easy model comparison

title: Comparing models — compare_models
code: library(plm) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘plm’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:dplyr’: #>  #>     between, lag, lead library(dplyr)  data(worldprod, package = 'jsar') countries <- c("Australia", "singapore", "china", "uk")  # comparison with same model (lm) for each country lm_models <- worldprod |>   filter(country_name %in% countries) |>   group_by(country_name) |>   group_map(~ lm(log_gdp ~ log_capital + log_labour , data = .x))  compare_models(lm_models, model_names = paste0('lm_',countries)) #> # A tibble: 7 × 5 #>   term        lm_Australia  lm_singapore  lm_china      lm_uk         #>   <chr>       <chr>         <chr>         <chr>         <chr>         #> 1 (Intercept) -0.518(0.177) -9.019(3.665) 0.754(0.127)  -0.462(1.091) #> 2 log_capital 1.36(0.174)   0.379(0.376)  0.346(0.097)* 0.51(0.027)** #> 3 log_labour  -1.297(0.412) 1.828(0.921)  1.139(0.445)  0.862(0.351)  #> 4 ####        ####          ####          ####          ####          #> 5 R$^2$       0.996         0.94          0.996         0.986         #> 6 Adj. R$^2$  0.995         0.935         0.995         0.985         #> 7 Num. obs.   28            28            28            28             # or with piping worldprod |>   filter(country_name %in% countries) |>   group_by(country_name) |>   group_map(~ lm(log_gdp ~ log_capital + log_labour , data = .x)) |>   compare_models( model_names = paste0('lm_',countries)) #> # A tibble: 7 × 5 #>   term        lm_Australia  lm_singapore  lm_china      lm_uk         #>   <chr>       <chr>         <chr>         <chr>         <chr>         #> 1 (Intercept) -0.518(0.177) -9.019(3.665) 0.754(0.127)  -0.462(1.091) #> 2 log_capital 1.36(0.174)   0.379(0.376)  0.346(0.097)* 0.51(0.027)** #> 3 log_labour  -1.297(0.412) 1.828(0.921)  1.139(0.445)  0.862(0.351)  #> 4 ####        ####          ####          ####          ####          #> 5 R$^2$       0.996         0.94          0.996         0.986         #> 6 Adj. R$^2$  0.995         0.935         0.995         0.985         #> 7 Num. obs.   28            28            28            28             lm_model <- lm(log_gdp ~ log_capital + log_labour, data = worldprod) plm_model <- plm::plm(log_gdp ~ log_capital + log_labour ,                       model = 'within', index = c('country_name', 'year'),                       data = worldprod)  compare_models(list(lm_model, plm_model),model_names = c('Pool', 'Panel')) #> # A tibble: 7 × 3 #>   term        Pool            Panel          #>   <chr>       <chr>           <chr>          #> 1 (Intercept) -0.577(0.016)** -              #> 2 log_capital 0.862(0.005)*** 0.586(0.011)** #> 3 log_labour  0.137(0.007)*** 0.291(0.028)** #> 4 ####        ####            ####           #> 5 R$^2$       0.963           0.89           #> 6 Adj. R$^2$  0.963           0.886          #> 7 Num. obs.   2296            2296

title: Fuzzy join for dates — fuzzy_join_dates
text: Finds n release dates immediately prior extraction date, release dates must prior extraction dates .

title: Fuzzy join for dates — fuzzy_join_dates
text: extraction_date extraction_date column dataframe date vector. release_date release_date column dataframe date vector. n number prior periods find. Defaults 1. len_hist length history use months. Ensures matching release dates old. Defaults 18 months.

title: Fuzzy join for dates — fuzzy_join_dates
text: dataframe enables fuzzy date join.

title: Fuzzy join for dates — fuzzy_join_dates
code: library(dplyr) #data with release dates df <- lfs_state |>      group_by(anzsco1_code, date) |>      summarise(emp = sum(emp), .groups = 'drop')  # extraction dates e_dt <- as.Date(c("2016-08-09", "2021-08-10")) # look at 4 prior quarters n_qtr <- 4 join_dates <- fuzzy_join_dates( e_dt, df$date, n = 3 * n_qtr, len_hist = (n_qtr + 1) * 12 )

code: library(ggplot2)  df <- data.frame( x = c("A", "B", "C", "D"), y = 1:4 )  g <- ggplot(  data = df,  mapping = aes(x = x, y = y)  ) + theme_minimal() +  theme(    legend.position = c(0.05, 0.95),    legend.justification = c(0, 1),    legend.title = element_blank(),    axis.title = element_blank()  ) #> Warning: A numeric `legend.position` argument in `theme()` was deprecated in ggplot2 #> 3.5.0. #> ℹ Please use the `legend.position.inside` argument of `theme()` instead.

text: yr year use. E.g. "2020" mth month use integer. E.g. "10" October n occurrence return. E.g. "1" first occurrence, "-2" second last occurrence wkday day week abbreviated 3 letter form. E.g. "Fri" Friday
